content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, my strategy would be to consider the long-term payoff rather than focusing on each individual round. In this game, choosing R gives higher rewards when the opponent chooses B (35$ compared to 0$), but also results in zero payout if both players choose R. On the other hand, choosing B guarantees a consistent payout of 40$ regardless of the opponent's choice, and yields a slightly lower payout when the opponent chooses R (0$ instead of 35$).

In 75 rounds, I expect my opponent to pick R relatively often in order to have a chance at the higher reward (45$) whenever I pick B. This is due to the higher potential payoff when both players choose different strategies. However, since I gain 0$ when we both pick R, I might end up with fewer payouts than if I consistently picked B.

Given these considerations, it seems logical to pick the strategy (B) that provides consistent lower-but-guaranteed rewards rather than risking zero payout by choosing R and hoping my opponent picks B more often. Therefore, my choice would be {B}.
